summary: Freddie Mercury -- the lead singer of Queen -- defies stereotypes and convention to become one of history's most beloved entertainers. The band's revolutionary sound and popular songs lead to Queen's meteoric rise in the 1970s. After leaving the group to pursue a solo career, Mercury reunites with Queen for the benefit concert Live Aid -- resulting in one of the greatest performances in rock 'n' roll history.

reviews.content: Bohemian Rhapsody was an interesting emotional movie. The story isn't 100% accurate but that didn't badder me too much. I think it was done this way to attract those who don't know Queen and it's history. The movie is a bit slow around the end of the first hour, but it does pickup after that. The Live Aid show is really full of emotions and energy. Love it. The acting is relatively solid. Rami Malek just carry this movie. His performance is amazing. The movie doesn't fall into scenes of debauchery and sex. It is mostly alluded. The music is great but not really presented in a chronological order. I give it 78%. I had a good time watching the movie, even if the middle section wasn't that engaging.

This movie is the muppet babies version of the real story. 

the last 20 minutes or so is just actors recreating the live aid concert, and the rest of the movie shows queen magically inventing all of their biggest hits.
It's a great movie. A story tied together with very good performances and characters. A great look at the new generation knowing how great Queen was

"Bohemian Rhapsody" (2018) for you. The film is a musical/drama directed by Bryan Singer and tells the story of the legendary British rock band, Queen, and its lead singer, Freddie Mercury. The film follows Freddie's rise to fame, his struggles with his sexuality, and the band's journey to become one of the most iconic musical acts of all time.

One of the biggest strengths of the film is the performances of the cast, particularly Rami Malek, who plays Freddie Mercury. Malek delivers an outstanding performance, capturing the essence of Freddie's flamboyant personality and his unique singing style. The supporting cast, including Gwilym Lee, Ben Hardy, and Joseph Mazzello, also deliver strong performances, bringing the rest of the band to life on screen.

The film's cinematography is also excellent, capturing the energy and spectacle of Queen's performances on stage. The movie's music is, of course, another standout aspect, featuring some of the band's most iconic songs such as "Bohemian Rhapsody," "We Will Rock You," and "Another One Bites the Dust." The film's use of music also helps to capture the emotion and energy of the band's journey.

On the negative side, the film's plot can feel a bit formulaic at times. The film follows a standard biopic structure, hitting all of the expected beats of a rock 'n' roll movie. Some of the characterizations also feel a bit shallow, particularly of Freddie's bandmates who are not given as much depth as they could have been.

Furthermore, some of the facts of the film are not entirely accurate, which can be frustrating for fans of Queen who are familiar with the band's history. However, this is to be expected to some degree in any biopic, as the filmmakers have to take some creative liberties to tell a compelling story.

In conclusion, "Bohemian Rhapsody" is a highly entertaining film that captures the spirit of Queen and its iconic lead singer. While it may not be the most groundbreaking or original movie, it is certainly worth watching for its excellent performances, music, and cinematography. Whether you're a fan of Queen or just looking for an enjoyable musical drama, "Bohemian Rhapsody" is a movie that will not disappoint.

Rami Malek gave a strong performance as Freddie Mercury, but other than that, nothing really stood out to me. Queen fans will enjoy this movie, but for the average moviegoer, it's really nothing more than a standard band biopic.
the film is okay at best, it just irritates me to no end with the number of inaccuracies in terms of stories & casting. why is joe mazzello john deacon. just why.

I would give Bohemian Rhapsody a 10/10 but on paper it is 8/10. While the film may not be historically accurate and may not be perfect, it feels like it is to me. Rami Malek is a perfect cast as Freddie Mercury, and the film provides a beautiful and tragic inside look at who he was. The constant use of Queen's music keeps things energetic, and the final twenty minutes are some of the best I've ever seen in a movie. Overall, Bohemian Rhapsody is a must-watch for fans of Queen, Freddie Mercury, or just music in general. Whether you're a diehard fan or just want to learn more about one of the greatest rock bands of all time, this film is sure to satisfy.

a fantastic idea poorly executed. we get almost no real shots of performances, many acted ones, and not much story. what's the point of trying to re-create the show of a man who's best ability was being a showman? and this at the expense of time that could have been used to develop more the story, give a better context and insight into the emotions and life of a man who left an imprint on the world. i'm looking forward to when someone re-attempts this.
Great performance by Rami Malek but not enough to make this a worth watching movie. The movie is just boring through most of its length.
This movie is filled to the brim with historical inaccuracies, but it's still pumps out to be OK.

"Bohemian Rhapsody" is really more about Queen the band rather than just the more interesting story of their flamboyant frontman. The story begins in 1970. Freddie ( Rami Malek ) is a regular attendee to live gigs and after a chance meeting with the rather bland but talented rock band Smile, he talks himself into being their new frontman.

The main issue the film has, is the lack of drama that was present during the meteoric rise to fame of the band Smile after both the change of frontman and name change to Queen. Freddie's story is completely different with a fascinating, deeply moving history that has more than enough drama and emotion to carry the film without sharing equally the screen time with the rest of the band.  Malek is outstanding as Freddie and totally believable as the self destructive star. Despite the lack of substance in the storytelling of the band it is full of their greatest hits particularly during recording sessions and song writing moments. However it is the focus on Freddie that steals the limelight and although " Bohemian Rhapsody" plays any sexuality issues and H.I.V. rather too briefly and quite safe, his mental torment and the demons he was battling with are portrayed brilliantly by Malek.  

" Bohemian Rhapsody's " closing act has Queen reforming, after a brief hiatus, to take part in the Live Aid Concert in 1985. These scenes are recreated with such visual excitement that the film elevates to a much higher level than anything previous. Malek reproduces very accurately the flamboyance, energy and charisma that oozed out of Freddie when he stole the show during that memorable concert. It's here the film ends, with Queen being hailed as the band that produced the best performance of the concert despite the who's who of artists and bands that took to the stage. 

Freddie's story would continue however for a further six years and it's quite a loss not to include these very important years. However "Bohemian Rhapsody" is an entertaining movie with an extremely memorable performance from the very talented Rami Malek.
Bloody awful! I'd recommend just watching a decent documentary and the original Live Aid performance.
One of the best movies I've ever seen.   Malik is incredible!

“electric - smashing - a crowd pleaser! this film delivers the noise & sound of one of the greatest bands of all time. the cast is impeccable & outstanding witty performances across the board. Rami Malek’s interpretation of Freddie Mercury is a beautiful honor in tribute to the man of rock and roll. he hands down deserved that man in gold. this film delivers such a way of storytelling that it hits it on the right spot in all the right moves. the finale scene at Live Aid, Wembley Stadium was flawlessly filmed, nothing like I ever seen on the big screen. It was like I was there! Thank you Bryan Singer & Dexter Fletcher!”
Really great tribute to Freddie. Great job and entertaining

I'm not a really big Queen fan (Surprise!) I'm not much on anthem rock, and they just slide right off me quite frankly. But this biography of Freddie Mercury is certainly compelling. Rami Marek is quite brilliant as Mercury here, from his small beginnings in Britain where he quite fortunately finds work with a bar band called Smile, which later evolved into Queen. We see how they struggled and succeeded along the way, mostly highlighting their most famous songs. All the actors playing the band performers are quite excellent. No qualms from me here.
The best acting performance from Rami Malek!

I generally think the movie is one to sit back and watch the glory happen. It tells the story of Queen, but in it's own twisted way, which is fascinating, but a little confusing to understand. I am a mega fan of Queen so I might be a little biased, but overall, it is a good movie.

Nothing is perfect, and not all biographical films that we have seen in the past were

Great movie! For any Queen fan it is a must see. Great acting and it creates an emotional atmosphere. Totally recommend it. The implementation of music is well achieved and the scenery as well as the imagery is greatly conceived and beautiful.
'Bohemian Rhapsody' is a jumble to please certain people, it's probably the most simulated movie of its kind, the worst thing is that they don't even try to hide it.

Watched the movie twice and enjoyed it even more the second time! Rami Malik is outstanding which has been confirmed by one of the few people who really know, Brian May. Most people forget that the movie was produced by 2 of the band members!
Perfect biopic. No flaws. Excellently cast.
Oscar winning lead performance aside, this glorified greatest hits compilation may leave fans wanting for more.

I was already familiar with Queen before watching "Bohemian Rhapsody," but it only enhanced my appreciation for Freddie Mercury as an individual. The movie does an incredible job highlighting his influence on music and the 70s culture. The way it presents his rise to fame with the formation of Queen, followed by his downfall due to an internal conflict of interest among the group and the societal stigma he later dealt with as a closeted homosexual, garners enthusiasm and sympathy without any artificial vibes. It truly immortalizes this legendary figure.

This film was entertaining, had many heartfelt moments, and renewed my love for this iconic band and its charismatic lead singer. Even with that being said, I felt the film dragged a bit at times and glossed over many important issues the band dealt with. Definitely one of my favorite music focused films however.
Its a great love letter to Queen. But it fails in the historical facts that are soo easy to fix. It should have ended in the Wembley concert of 86
Horrible filmmaking, directing, editng, writting...good band. The point is these music biopics are very generic, poorly done and not cinema
It deserves more love than it got
Hitting its high notes and low notes. Bohemian Rhapsody is perfectly paced even if Freddie's moments are in some areas badly presented but it will always be the defining film of Freddie Mercury.
Another proof why Rami Malek is a fantastic actor.

I enjoyed this film for most of the duration but it was that final scene, the infamous set during Live Aid, that I found really, particularly engrossing and memorable, much like (I imagine) the real life performance.

I felt that Rami Malek did give a particularly good performance as Freddie Mercury. Freddie's undoubted charisma comes across quite well on screen. Of course there's the fact that (as some critics/others have mentioned) some (sexual related) details were glossed over, shall I say, which I believe was mainly done to allow the film to get the lower 12 rating, rather than a 15. I wouldn't say it entirely detracted from the film - it is perhaps a little sanitised, perhaps there's an element of artificiality about it, a bit but the film is still a decent, pretty solid film regardless. There are some witty lines of dialogue and I enjoyed seeing the group (Queen, obviously) rise in popularity and how Freddie got on (or not) with the other band members and the like. 

This is a fun film to watch if you want to have a bit of a sing along and its intriguing in terms of the plot. I like Queens music but I can't say I knew much about the history of the group, so I found this both an entertaining and an insightful film. How true it is to the history of the group, I can't really say but as a film itself, its a decent watch and so I'd recommend it on that basis (rock on!!).

Terrific how they start it off with the iconic Live Aid concert. I don't think anyone else could have played Freddie other than Rami. It's like he got into his skin and became him. Not only does he look like him, but he has all his mannerisms. It's insane. It's crazy how much Freddie got ridiculed for his big teeth. It didn't matter to him though, he used it as fuel and internalized it into confidence. He was born to be a frontman, a performer, and destined to be one of the most iconic and greatest voices in rock history. Really cool to see how creative they were to experiment with sound in the studio when they were recording their first song. Wow, the actress that plays Freddie's girlfriend is beautiful. Oh wow the actor who plays Little Finger in GOT is their manager! I love how Mike Myers taps into his Fat Bastard character for his role in this movie as the crabby record company headman. I love how Bohemian Rhapsody was a tune that echoed in Freddie's head, he felt a strong connection with the melody he came up with. It was almost like something spiritual in nature that was being gifted to him.

It's kind of a treat getting to see a glimpse into Freddie's personal life. Seeing how David Munns kind of led Freddie down the wrong path whilst manipulating him was something I had no idea happened in Freddie's life. How petty and disgusting of him to go on national television and spill all of Freddie's secrets and personal life like he did, what a trashy human being. I'm glad Freddie was able to move past that phase in his life and throw him out like yesterdays trash, but of course it wouldn't have been possible if it wasn't for Mary who woke him up quite literally and then made him realize everything.

It's so inspirational to see how much of a positive impact Queen has made on the world, and especially seeing how much money they raked in during their performing at Live Aid was insane. I love how Mary, even through all the ups and downs with Freddie, still was a part of Freddie's life, always there supporting him. I thought that was beautiful, I feel like we could all use a loyal and wonderful friend like Mary in our lives. 

The movie's got a good sense of humor. The pacing is wonderful. The story is told beautifully with elegance. Filmed with a deft eye and a keen sense to detail, style and aesthetic. It all looks wonderful. The movie really pulled me in and kept me entertained. That's what I want, what I need from a movie.

What a wonderful movie. I thoroughly enjoyed it, all of it. An unexpectedly inspiring and uplifting movie, I wasn't ready for all the emotions and feels it offered. There were definitely a couple of moments where I teared up either out of joy or excitement. The only problem I have with this movie is that I wish they showed the final years of Freddie. It was almost like they were trying to avoid showing as much of that part of Freddie's life as possible. Which I get it, there's nothing really happy or uplifting about it, but it was definitely an integral part of his life as well. It felt like the producers were scared of showing that side because it would have maybe darkened up the already exciting and inspiring tone that they established throughout the movie. But in fact it could have elevated it to the next level. There's nothing wrong in showing the dark side of life and people just as long as its done with taste and good style. Overall, I'd watch this movie again sometime and I definitely recommend it to everyone.

4 years ago- The starmaking performance of Rami Malek and the chemistry among the actors in the iconic band does little to aide a story that just seems to bullet point the band's moments without ever truly examining the men in the band itself.

Either way, it feels a little lacking and the final twenty minutes is simply a poor man's recreation of a gig you can find on YouTube anyway. Felt slightly lazy. I'm not a huge Queen fan anyway and it was all a bit meh.

Easily the best rock-u-mentary EVER. Long live the QUEEN!

This is such a great and emotional movie, and captures who Freddie Mercuray was. And don't get me started on the music.

Bogged down with awful editing and a lacklustre script, Bohemian Rhapsody offers little more than a preview of Queens greatest hits rather than a compelling biopic of one of the worlds greatest bands. Tame and uninspired it may appeal to Queen die hards with an endless amount of fan service, yet to those who wanted more, you may have a more enjoyable time listening to the true music.
The acting is impeccable!

I didn't know much about Queen and Freddie Mercury before watching the film, and besides the pieces I remember from the film, I don't know much about them after either. It has been years since I watched this movie, but the biggest thing I remember is the performance Rami Malek puts on. Definitely the highlight of the film.
Seriously its so good! It's nice not having the usual arc of degenerates, drug addicts, overdoses and suicide in a band's bio. Plus the music is obviously incredible
Queen is the greatest

This film may not be a masterpiece, but it has filled my heart with so much happiness and joy that I think it's going to burst (sorry for the cheesiness). Freddie Mercury, Brian May, Roger Taylor, and John Deacon are so beautifully portrayed that I forgot it wasn't them at times; the performances were so on point and so powerful that you could feel the energy burst through the screen. ¿ Have you seen Wayne's world's iconic vehicle scene? Imagine a room full of people doing the same thing; they can't help but sing along (let's be honest, it's impossible not to).

I was excited to see it. But... I wasn't crazy about Rami Malec as Freddy, he seems like a good actor, but.... the overbite and negative/calm demeanor of his character was off putting.   Besides that, It's a good movie! I love documentaries, especially about music. I know this is just a movie, but I love to see the process.
Ramis talent was impressive.  The entire cast was perfect.
Waiting for BR2. More Queen, less Freddy Mercury.

Never before had I wanted to see a movie more than twice before. Not only I liked it because it's the story of Freddie Mercury but also because of the actor's performance. 
Only the movies that I really loved are the ones that I recommend. That's why I hope you watch and enjoy this movie as much as I do.

Have a lot of appreciation for Queen. Not a favourite band of mine by all means, but it is difficult to not understand their importance and appeal. They had some iconic songs (namely "Bohemian Rhapsody", "We Will Rock You", "We Are the Champions" and "Don't Stop Me Now") and Freddie Mercury's immediately recognisable vocals and Brian May's virtuosic guitar playing were always out of this world.

'Bohemian Rhapsody' fascinated me when hearing about it and became most of my most anticipated films for the year. When hearing some negativity for the film, my expectations lowered a little, but saw it anyway because it did look and sound good. It did turn out to be a good decision, it is good to see that others here loved it and don't agree with the mixed critical reception respectfully.

Sure there are clichés (such as what some of the rest of Queen say) , but very few films are not and many are much worse in this regard. Like a lot of biopics, there are inaccuracies that may drive die-hard Queen fans into a frenzy, and the odd factual distortion, but again 'Bohemian Rhapsody' is not the first or worst film to do this and am going to judge it as a film on its own and not on a documentary level.

As a film on its own terms, 'Bohemian Rhapsody' has an awful lot to admire. Getting the issues out of the way, the ones that could have been handled much better was the with the revelation of Freddie Mercury's AIDs diagnosis to the rest of the band, could have been done with more tact and less crass (like saying what it was a consequence of) and revealed too early and at the wrong time, and the implications with the phone ringing off post-taking centre stage that the event was a flop when it actually was a triumph.

Some of the early parts were a touch rushed as well, Mercury's ascent to stardom could have been less breakneck.

However, 'Bohemian Rhapsody' is stylishly film and evokes the period beautifully. As to be expected, the songs are incredible and will be embedded in your brain for a long time, then again it is Queen of course. They are affectionately staged and performed in a way that made me remember what made me appreciate Queen in the first place.

Didn't find the script that simplistic or cliff-notes like, while there is a nice mix of moment of laughter, tension and tears and enough parts that entertained and informed, if not as in depth as it should. The story is never dull and the Live Aid depiction is both rousing and poignant. It's capably directed and while all the performances are fine if underused, it is Rami Malek's outstanding turn as Mercury that will live long in the memory, true to what made Mercury so interesting a person and performer without being an impersonation.

Concluding, impressively done and better than anticipated. 8/10 Bethany Cox

This was an entertaining movie about one of the best performers and bands ever. Queen was so many hits that the music alone makes for a great time. Rami Malek was a perfect fit to play the iconic Freddie mercury and he won an Oscar for this movie for a reason. Although nobody can be like Freddie, Rami came as close as you can get.

If you were a Queen fan ( and I was) then there's enough in just rehearing great songs but as a film it's not great. It feels like a made for tv film rather than a cinematic experience. I couldn't get to grips with the guy playing Freddie, over exaggerating his mannerisms and leaving me unconvinced
Terrible acting, an insult to Freddie in my opinion, a better look-alike Freddie might have been better instead of some geek!

I've been a die-hard Queen fan since the Sheer Heart Attack album. Before I continue, let me state that I know the difference between a bio pic & a documentary.

BOHEMIAN RHAPSODY is a stellar production, & if it brings more people to the music of Queen, then God bless it. However, as a die-hard fan again, I'm put off by the historical inaccuracies of the movie. Apologies to the millions who love this film, but I can't get past them. I'm better served by the DAYS OF OUR LIVES documentary. The real story is much more fascinating & entertaining.

It's hard not to be impressed by the performances in Bohemian Rhapsody, and not only the leading actor Rami Malek in his brilliant effort to portray the rock icon Freddie Mercury, but also solid performances from almost every actor, and most of all by the production designer staff, personal scenografic and musical instrument instructors, and the crew making it technically possible to get a pretty amazing end result. All this is in the details and you just want to believe what you see. It's also easy to get sentimental with a final that is kind of magic. This is all perfect. However, with just over two hours the film isn't too long, and could have dwelled more on and not just skip why and how Farrokh Bulsara became Freddie Mercury, what made him into one of the greatest stage personas, pop legends and composers of all time. Sadly the first part of the film jumps too easily over this pivotal question, and it basically continues to be unsettled throughout the film. Also the other band members and some of the most crucial people around Queen or the band's leading performer are one dimensional. The directors don't manage to show us the whole human and fully grasp the intensity of what recognized Freddie Mercury. It is a lot to dive into, but without this the portrait is too shallow and the film fails to become as legendary as the man it wants to paint a biographical picture of. Nevertheless, for fans this isn't a bad tribute, just not a great one.
Fans of the group will definitely love it. im not a fan but the movie was good.

I'm not a huge Queen fan but this is a great movie. They have managed to get actors that looks like Freddie, Roger, Brian and John but I think that sometimes, Freddies mouth gets a little bit exaggaratedly big. But they've got a great story and for sure worth seeing.

Bohemian Rhapsody is a biopic of the legendary British rock band, Queen. Rami Malek is a spitting image of the band's lead singer, Freddie Mercury. He delivered a brilliant performance. Some are even saying that it's worthy of an Oscar award. The movie itself was well-directed. Great cinematography and script. Musical score is excellent since it showcased the band's biggest hits. It will surely give fans goosebumps. Very entertaining and has a lot of character development, which mainly focused on Mercury's life story. He had a strong, mystifying and charismatic character that helped lead the band to superstardom. I'm glad they didn't try to sugarcoat his personality and showed us who he really was -- strengths, weaknesses and all. So, aside from showing us Queen's journey, it also showed us Freddie Mercury's struggles, frustrations and unwavering determination. Highly entertaining, especially if you're a rock music fan.

Riveting lead performance, which gives a great impression of the man, the performer and the music. But key turning points in the story are completely distorted or outright fabrications, which is really disappointing.
Malek does a grand job portraying Freddie, the story was well executed, thoroughly enjoyed it.
Formulaic biopic fabricates practically everything. Didn't exactly rock me.

I like Queen, I love classic rock, and I think Freddie was a great musician...but this movie was shite, and focused on drama as opposed to the genius musicians all of these guys are, rather than exaggerating stories to create drama in the movie and disregarding Taylor and May, and the other fella (lol), Overrated, but yeah lol, shite-box material

Beautiful but it's full of errors, for example We Will Rock You in the film was created when Freddie already has a mustache when it is not true, not to mention Ray Foster and Paul Prenter who do not even exist, the rest is all OK.
Enjoyed it. No it’s not perfectly accurate and it’s historical timeline and facts that’s not what the movies about

Sure, another biopic without actually telling the truth and legendary life from the only Mercury, I guess we never wanted it to become this way, and no one will go to cinema for it...... Oh! It's the whole scene from that live concert! I guess we did need this! Let's give it another 3 stars and a bunch of Oscar!
pretty epic movie. great performance by the lead.
Good to see what it was like seeing Queen's in the stage.

Impeccable look-alike casting nails these four lads, especially Freddie Mercury. But the script reduces them to two-dimensional figurines, something akin to the animated Beatles in "Yellow Submarine". As a fan, the first half hour was admirable. The rest of it found me checking my watch.
Less a film and more of a feature-length karaoke performance but I'm here for it!

Three things I love about this movie:
1. The acting is phenominal, especially by Rami Malek and Gwilym Lee.
2. The plot is very entertaining. Even though a lot of people knew the basic Queen timeline already, I think they still made it very entertaining to watch, just by making a few very small changes to it.
3. The adaption of the Live Aid performance is AWESOME. I actually like the movie version more than the original. They made it almost perfectly synchronized to the original version, with the movement etc.
ABSOLUTE MUST SEE!!!!!
PS: I hope there is coming a sequel :)

Rami Malek was amazing here and did a great job of capturing the essence of Freddie Mercury.  The problem with him being so good is it reduced the other characters to single dimensions.  The actual movie is a bit of a mess some scenes connect awkwardly but it's energy overcomes that just enough to make it very enjoyable.
While being terrifically acted, Bohemian Rhapsody lacks any sort of heart, which is essentially all that can carry conventional Oscar-bait.
Inaccurate film but it was enjoyable
An incredible story about a legendary classic rock band. 5/5
An amazing masterpiece. This movie is all I wish in a musical. The story of Freddy Mercury is awesome and the way they narrated was spectacular. The music is amazing and Rami Malek is the goat.

The story of Freddie Mercury is a tragic and hard-edged story about a immigrant gay man who did drugs and died of AIDS. The way this movie tells this story comes off as hollow and sanitised, there is so much inaccurate stuff in this movie like the fact that Queen broke up as a band because they were upset that Freddie Mercury got a deal for a solo album which upsets the band in the movie which never happened in real life because Roger Taylor released a solo album in the late 70s early 80s and in the movie Freddie Mercury tells the band he has AIDS a week before Live Aid in 1985 although he wasn't diagnosed until 1987. This is not the worst movie I have ever seen in my life but it's not exactly the greatest either

An enjoyable film but one that never feels like it truly knows what it wants to be. Is it trying to make us marvel at the creative talents of Mercury, or feel unsettled and sad at his elusive, lonely personal life? Are we supposed to feel sympathy with the band who need to comply with his antics? Or take inspiration for how energised and on-board they are with his creative direction?

The film flirts with the underlying tragedy of his private life and the illness that inevitably claims his life, but keeps it at arm's length to prevent the audience from getting sad when there's rock music to enjoy.

So it's a good film but not an excellent one. Rami Malek is astonishing though, without question.
Sometimes You lose others pursuing yourself. Love “We are the Champions”

Such a great movie depicts the biography of such a great man. I`ve been listening to Queen since childhood when my dad introduced me to their music. This movie made me feel a lot of stuff, it truly touched my soul.
Brilliant performances that rocked our house.

A biopic is a film meant to dramatize a non-functional person's life. Some creative license is used to provide exposition. Maybe some scenes are created to move the story along. 
This is not a biopic. Most of the movie is simply invented by the writers and director. For example, Freddie didn't meet the other band members behind a van after their show; they were already roommates. There was no backlash against the Bohemian Rhapsody song; everyone loved it at the start. The band wasn't inspired to perform at Live Aid by Freddie's courage in the face of AIDS; he wasn't diagnosed with that until two years after that show. 
The movie at all times is heading towards that Live Aid performance, which was recreated shot for shot with the original footage. This begs the question: why recreate what Queen did in 1985 with actors when you literally have the original footage?

"Bohemian Rhapsody" is a foot-stomping celebration of Queen, their music and their extraordinary lead singer Freddie Mercury. Freddie defied stereotypes and shattered convention to become one of the most beloved entertainers on the planet. The film traces the meteoric rise of the band through their iconic songs and revolutionary sound. They reach unparalleled success, but in an unexpected turn Freddie, surrounded by darker influences, shuns Queen in pursuit of his solo career. Having suffered greatly without the collaboration of Queen, Freddie manages to reunite with his bandmates just in time for Live Aid. While bravely facing a recent AIDS diagnosis, Freddie leads the band in one of the greatest performances in the history of rock music. Queen cements a legacy that continues to inspire outsiders, dreamers and music lovers to this day.

It received mixed reviews from critics; while Singer's direction, portrayal of Mercury's sexuality and lives of the other band members were criticized, Malek's performance and the music sequences received praise. The film also contains a number of historical inaccuracies. It became a major box office success, grossing over $903 million worldwide on a production budget of about $50 million, becoming the sixth-highest-grossing film of 2018 worldwide and setting the all-time box office records for the biopic and drama genres. "Bohemian Rhapsody" received numerous accolades, including a leading four wins at the 91st Academy Awards for Best Actor (Malek), Best Film Editing, Best Sound Editing and Best Sound Mixing; it was also nominated for Best Picture. The film also won Best Motion Picture – Drama at the 76th Golden Globe Awards, and was nominated for the Producers Guild of America Award for Best Theatrical Motion Picture and BAFTA Award for Best British Film, while Malek won the Golden Globe, Screen Actors Guild and BAFTA for Best Actor. On review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes critical consensus reads: "Bohemian Rhapsody hits a handful of high notes, but as an in-depth look at a beloved band, it offers more of a medley than a true greatest hits collection." Owen Gleiberman of Variety wrote: "Rami Malek does a commanding job of channeling Freddie Mercury's flamboyant rock-god bravura, but Bryan Singer's middle-of-the-road Queen biopic rarely lives up to the authenticity of its lead performance." Paul Whitington, writing for the Irish Independent, gave the film 3/5 stars, saying: "Bohemian Rhapsody is not big on subtlety: it tells Freddie's story loudly, taking dramatic shortcuts, over-neatly conflating events and reducing most of the surrounding characters to single dimensions. Some of the dialogue's a bit heavy-handed too, but I must say I was thoroughly entertained."

I don't know how much of ‘Bohemian Rhapsody' is based on reality, but it's Rami Malek's superb central performance (the rest of the cast is pretty good, too) as Queen's legendary frontman, Freddie Mercury, that is the driving force, managing to capture a flamboyant, diva-esque side that is in stark contrast to the various shades of emotional pain he goes through, mainly due to his sexuality and a feeling of alienation. As for the rest of it: it's mostly a boiled down account of the band's decisions as the years go by – neither particularly exciting, nor particularly boring. But then, of course, there's the music, the absolutely iconic music that is spread throughout the film, ending it on a truly epic note.

Malek certainly deserves the praise he got, but I don't know that the film as a whole does – yes, it's good and entertaining, but not outstanding.

This film tells the story of legendary rock band, Queen. They are well known all over the world to this day for their musicianship as well as their late lead singer, Freddie Mercury. Mercury's life seemed to be in the public eye for all to see, but in this film you see a side of him you've never seen before. You learn the secrets behind their hits, you learn about the bond the band had, their downfall, their revival. It's fascinating to see. The movie takes you through the bands entire musical career from the very beginning, up until Live Aid. You get to see how the band forms, their musical evolution. You learn more about their recording techniques than ever before and you're able to see exactly what influenced their music. You meet Mary Austin, the love of Mercury's life, Paul Prenter, the villain, and Jim Hutton, his partner until he passed away. You meet the bands very first producers and managers, their long time manager "Miami" Beach, as well as some not so cooperative record labels who doubted their more musically diverse tracks like "Bohemian Rhapsody". Speaking of, so much of the "crazy" writing that redefined rock and roll is explained. You see tracks through the writing process, start to finish. The film also shows what was going on behind the scenes for Mercury. From his realization of his sexuality, to testing HIV positive, we see what he was truly going through. One of my very favorite parts of the film is the Live Aid performance. From the music to the realistic look of the crowd, you feel like you are there watching it live. The emotion in the arena is indescribable and you can feel it through the screen. The film is well researched and incredibly accurate, as I have done some fact checking. You will love this film whether you are a Queen fan or not. It is more than a bio-epic, it's a story about real people. The revolutionary band that we all know and love, on screen in their prime decade later. What more could we ask for? This movie is worth your time, it's the kind of film you can watch time and time again and catch something new every time. I would recommend this film to anyone and everyone within the PG-13 rating. This is an absolute must see and arguably THE movie of 2018! Grab some popcorn and your old Queen t-shirt and get ready to shed a few tears, sing along, and smile a whole lot!

Lead by a strong performance from lead Rami Malek as legendary Queen front man Freddie Mercury, Bohemian Rhapsody delivers a lively and inspiring recount of how the band formed and succeed in becoming a global phenomenon, still admired to this day. While some aspects of the film are not told with the greatest accuracy, especially that Freddie Mercury battle with being positive for HIV/AIDS, the film does accurately portray Freddie's real life relationship with Mary Austin (Lucy Boynton), him many male partners and sexual encounters, and his relationship with band-mates Brian May (Gwilym Lee), Roger Taylor (Ben Hardy) and John Deacon (Joseph Mazzello). Also of interest is the band's relationship with Ray Foster (Mike Myers), an EMI executive who hated their classic song Bohemian Rhapsody, and Paul Prenter (Allen Leech), Mercury's personal manager and lover. Culminating with the 1985 Live Aid charity concert held in part at Wembley Stadium in London. Mercury reunited with his former queen band-mates to perform some of their greatest hits, and eventually Bohemian Rhapsody again reaching number one on the radio charts as Freddie Mercury succumbed to HIV/AIDS and died. Although being far from perfect, it does showcase the triumphs and some failures of one of the greatest Rock n' Roll bands that ever existed.

I don't think this movie deserves the praise nor scorn it has received, and therefore believe my score is fair at a solid (77) — as I write this, it has an (61/85) on RT, so I've fallen a little closer to the audience than the critics. Rami Malek as the lightning-in-a-bottle talent of Freddie Mercury was much better than I had expected (even though he won the Oscar for his portrayal) and he largely carried this movie from start to finish. I suppose my expectations were low considering Bohemian Rhapsody also won Best Film Editing, an award that was famously eviscerated on the internet immediately thereafter. And let me tell you, the "pitch" scene that made its rounds on social media is as bad as it came off during the wave of criticism and almost gave me motion sickness. Moreover, why on Earth would Queen need to pitch themselves to Little Finger (Aidan Gillen)? It takes about 6 seconds to know that Mercury was a generational, if not centurational (?), talent. Sometimes the pacing was strange and the band didn't seem to have the issues typically associated with rock bands. Maybe this was accurate, which is fine, but sometimes they almost seemed to finish each other's sentences and it came off as corny. Lucy Boynton as Mary deserved an Oscar for having the world's worst on-screen gaydar. The LiveAid ending was a lovely touch, even if it didn't have the personal significance to Freddie in real life as it had in the film. Basically, this is a fun movie that had taken — like usual — plenty of liberties with historical accuracy to make an overall enjoyable film. Oh, and there were numerous cats that occupied Freddie's home throughout and they all receive 100/100s, 10 gold stars, of course.

It spends too much time trying to dig the tears out of us that we don't get to see the true fall of Freddie. I also wish the film included more musical elements, but that wasn't their goal so overall the music they did have was nice. So despite Rami being a standout actor, the movie suffers from bad pacing, uninteresting side characters, and doesn't balance Freddie's conflicts as well as I'd hoped for.

While this was a great year for music films big and small -- from the affecting "A Star Is Born" to the sweetly comfortable "Hearts Beat Loud" to the darkly raunchy music industry satire "Stadium Anthems" -- the box office behemoth that was "Bohemian Rhapsody" doesn't make that short list, and this despite having truly elite biographical material to mold from. It will always be a missed opportunity.

Let's concede that Rami Malek was able to ape Freddie Mercury to the absolute letter -- in fact his performance is in some ways made greater by its standing as the uncontested greatest attribute within an otherwise very intentionally compromised story. Because ultimately, "Bohemian Rhapsody" is not a product reflective of Queen's gritty and hard-hitting era, but instead fully embraces today's high sheen, honesty-be-damned times. And it just didn't have to be that way. Even the film's bolder aspirations are squashed by unnecessary interference from awkward depictions of untruthful shortcuts designed to placate a mass audience. Take the oft-heralded recreation of the band's legendary set at LiveAid: Indeed, so much care is taken to get that right, including the admirably un-Hollywood risk of reproducing that performance in full. Yet their set isn't actually left to play out in its consuming glory as advertised; instead, it's shamelessly intercut with goofball images of a phone bank in which LiveAid organizer Bob Geldolf glumly looks over a group of customer service reps with phones that at one moment are silent, but within seconds of Queen's set begin ringing triumphantly en masse. The sad insinuation is made that no other acts were able to solicit phone calls until Queen went on, and that once they did, viewers readily interrupted their own consumptions of the performance to desperately make 1-800-calls in real-time (!). "Bohemian Rhapsody" is filled with many such patronizing and irresponsible creative decisions.

Queen's trust and estate has surely bankrolled from "Bohemian Rhapsody" as a film, and as a catalyst for sparking renewed interest in the band's catalog and continued live performances. But in terms of legacy, the choices here feel terribly thin and short-sighted. Here's hoping that at end-of-life, the members of Queen who outlasted Mercury won't be consumed by the existential regret of having documented their band's legitimate glory with this distorted and saccharine veneer of their well-earned lives.

It's surprisingly quite tame for what claims to be a Queen biopic (will get to that later). There are sex and drugs implied along with heavy partying but nothing too much. Swearing is words like sh*t damn, hell, and one F bomb quietly thrown in, but are infrequent. 
Now on to the review itself, as a hardcore Freddie and Queen fan was highly disappointed. The movie was grossly inaccurate, mostly in its portrayal of Freddie himself. The movie claims to be a Queen biopic but then instead chooses to  focus solely on Freddie with his band mates being pushed to the background. But then if it were choosing to be a Freddie Mercury biopic, it leaves out probably the most important aspects of his life such as his collaborations with Montserrat Caballé, Micheal Jackson, and of course David Bowie. (He did do a fantastic opera for a bit in his later years!) Also brushes over his sexuality and tries to put a label on him which is the last thing he wanted. He thought he may be bisexual but according to those closest to him he described himself as gay. No one knows for sure except Freddie himself but it is known he had a blatant preference for men. 
They make Mary Austin appear to be a sweet innocent heroine (she did pay the filmmakers and had a hand in making it so I'm not surprised) when in reality she was a questionable person who did terrible things and still does them to this day. 
The casting was meh, Brian may was spot on and John deacon looked passible, but I felt roger Taylor and of course Freddie were grossly miscast. Rogers actor looked nothing like him whatsoever. Rami Malek did nail Freddie's mannerisms and speaking voice however his appearance threw it off. His strangely shaped jaw and bug eyes did not capture the look whatsoever, coupled with his small stature and comically overexagerrated teeth. It felt like watching a caricature of Mercury. 
Overall disappointment but of course the music was the best part. Disappointed they left out some of their smaller, amazing songs and chose only to focus on the ones we've all heard a billion times over. 

If you're a fan you'll walk away feeling disappointed and if you're a new fan from the movie, you'll have this twisted vision of what Queen was and who Freddie Mercury really was.

I love Queen and Freddie Mercury. So after watching this, I was disappointed. They make the music the emphasis of the movie and not the band. Its meant to be a crowd pleasing movie. For the real Queen fans your gonna leave mad cause half of the movie is a bunch of lies. R.I.P. Freddy Mercury - one of the greatest performers ever.

I'm not sure I should write a review but what I'll say is that after the first 45 minutes I thought two hours of boredom had gone by. When I saw I was mistaken and I still hadn't even seen half of it, I thought I should do my best to power through as it may get better. 

After another hour (in my mind) only 15 minutes had passed. I had to X out of it, I just couldn't take it. For one thing, none of the characters were likable. Rami Malek as the lead gave me nothing to care for. While he was somewhat interesting at first, as it dragged on, nothing changed. There was not much depth and I had no empathy or understanding of Mercury's difficulties or his genius. So much seemed just like cliche guess work of behavior with little insight into the human being he was. Same for all of the other characters though they had far less screen time. For these reasons I could not be pulled in or interested. A lot of the problem was the script. It just didn't provide scenes that developed character or story. The direction was also at fault for that. 

In any case, after an hour that felt like four, I simply couldn't take it any longer. I refuse to waste my time on movies that can't pull me in after that much time. A movie should have a plot twist at 45 minutes into it. One that's pivotal and draws the viewer in even more. That's just a basic rule of screenwriting. I don't recall seeing anything like that, I was simply bored.

What am I watching?  A compilation of live concerts?  A movie hasn't done its work just because the story is about a famous person, event or thing: it has a lot more to do, which this movie doesn't do.

Definitely deserving of its good reviews, Bohemian Rhapsody paints a portrait of Freddie Mercury's life and does a decent job of also capturing the essence of the band Queen. My only gripe with this film is that it deliberately avoids the downfall of Freddie Mercury, and thus leaves an air of incompleteness. I do understand the band's decision to end the movie on a positive note, probably one of the highest points of his/Queen's career: the Live Aid performance.

Looking at this as objectively as possible, the real centrepiece of this biopic is Rami Malek's stellar performance as Mercury, he encapsulates the Queen legend's mannerisms and performance nuances perfectly, with the Live Aid depiction a particular highlight, Malek had clearly done his homework. One however can't ignore Gwilym Lee's portrayal of Brian May, which was pitch perfect, and for a few brief moments I forgot I was watching a movie depiction of the band, that's how good Lee's portrayal and likeness was. Other than the performances of the primary cast, the movie in and of itself just left me wanting a little bit; visually and in terms of music and sound mixing it was fabulous, however the plot for me was a little unevenly balanced, and certain elements were changed in order to enhance the dramatic tension (though that often happens in biopics). It is a wonderful tribute to Queen at their peak, but if you're expecting a cinematic masterpiece you will end up being disappointed, as the overall narrative is at times wonky and unengaging, though if you're a die hard Queen fan you will likely love it.

However, if you're looking for an enjoyable ride and a fun story, all placed to some of the best hit songs of the industry, this is the movie for you. Where it may lack in fact and professionalism it is made up for in comedy and personality. Rami Malek does a great job becoming Freddie Mercury, specifically in his recreation of the legendary Live Aid performance. It is a good watch for anyone who enjoys biopics and laid back storytelling, or who would simply like to be momentarily brought back to the days of the great Mr. Mercury.

Lacking in any real emotional range and a “paint by numbers” biopic script, it is the most overrated film of 2018. Not exactly sure what I just witnessed. The movie began and proceeded at such a frantic pace I wasn't sure what was happening. I thought maybe we'd be watching the life and death of Mercury in a matter of 20 minutes. 

I resent how insincere the film felt. There were endearing moments with some real human connection but Rami Malek failed so hard to bring any amount of depth to Mercury. I loved Malek in Mr. Robot. His disconnected scattered demeanor fit that character so perfectly. Unfortunately Malek wasn't able to leave Elliot Anderson behind while portraying a pop rock superstar. He kept taking me out of the story by reminding I was just watching a movie. That is always a bad sign and mark of a not so great film. If you can't draw and keep someone engaged, it's a matter of a lackluster performance. 

I thought the other actors showed decent and sometimes strong  talent. I believed what they were selling me though the pace and feeling of "we need to hit all the bullet points in 2 hours" didn't allow for enough emotional realness to actually feel connected to any of the characters. 

The movie was entertaining and I truly felt for Mercury in his illness and dying. I'll give it that. 

Sigh. I'm disappointed. I don't think I'd feel so strongly if the movie hadn't won best actor and best picture. I really don't get it. True Queen and Mercury fans deserved better. I can only hope that someone will retell his story beautifully and honor the memory of Freddie Mercury properly. Fingers crossed.

The rest of the cast does a great job too, and the screenplay does a good job telling Queen's story, even though some of the things in it aren't accurate and didn't happen. Overall, it's one of the best music biopics of all time and is something I highly recommend.

Amazing movie. Blew me away. I wish they showed more intimate moments of Freddie Mercury's relationships but I understand that they would've taken away from the focus on Queen as a band. I learned so much about Queen. Loved it. Must see if you like classic rock or Queen.
